note.p: John C. Van Duzer was a newspaper editor, Union military officer during the Civil War, and telegraph official.

Born on August 30, 1827, in Erie County, New York, Van Duzer was educated in public schools and apprenticed at a newspaper office in Utica. He also gained training in telegraphy and railroad work. When the Civil War broke out, Van Duzer volunteered for the military and eventually was commissioned as an officer in the Union telegraph service.

Van Duzer ran into conflict with General Ulysses S. Grant during the war over telegraph operations, and was arrested by Grant for defying his orders regarding the use of military telegraph lines for civilian messages. Van Duzer was supported by other officials, including Secretary of War Edwin Stanton, and was released from military confinement and returned to service. He finished the war as a lieutenant colonel and in charge of the United States military telegraph system within the Military Division of the Mississippi.

Following the war, Van Duzer helped develop telegraph service within the south. Then, in 1879, he returned north and to newspaper editing, spending nearly two decades as the editor of the Iron Port in Escanaba, Michigan. He died on March 3, 1898. He was married to Lavinia Olive Norton and had five children. Van Duzer is buried in Lakeview Cemetery, Escanaba, Michigan.

(FindaGrave; The Weekly Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, March 12, 1898; Timothy B. Smith, The Decision Was Always My Own, 23; Clayton R. Newell and Charles R. Shrader, A History of the Regular Army in the Civil War, 82)
John C. Van Duzer belonged to the following social groups:
James Madison Wells was an anti-secession figure in Louisiana during the Civil War who served as that state's governor during Reconstruction.

Born to a wealthy family on January 7, 1808, near Alexandria, Louisiana, Wells attended school in Kentucky and Connecticut before studying law in Cincinnati, Ohio. He moved back to Louisiana in 1829 to oversee plantations owned by his family. He inherited large tracts of land and became a wealthy slaveowner. Not content with being only a planter, Wells became active in public office and political circles. He was first appointed sheriff of Rapides Parish in 1840 and participated in Whig meetings. He changed parties in the 1850s, joining the Democrats and supporting Stephen Douglas during the 1860 presidential election. He opposed secession and became a highly controversial figure in Louisiana during the Civil War. Confederate officials arrested him for his Unionist sentiments, but he was released. Later in the war, he led Unionist partisans in irregular warfare against Confederate military activities in Louisiana.

Due to his staunch Unionist position, Wells became lieutenant governor in the pro-Union Louisiana state government in 1864. He was then made governor in 1865 and generally worked with federal Reconstruction officials. However, Wellsâ€™s support for the rights of free Blacks and former slaves was inconsistent. He supported Black voting rights, but appointed several former Confederates with white supremacist attitudes to state positions. Wells did little to prevent racial tension and violence in Louisiana in 1866, leading to his removal by U.S. Army officials in 1867.

Wells supported the Republican Party during the 1870s and accepted an appointment to oversee voting returns in Louisiana in 1873. His efforts helped overturn some fraudulent elections which had benefitted conservative white Democrats. He then received a federal position in 1874 as surveyor of customs at the Port of New Orleans and remained in that office until 1880.
Wells died on February 28, 1899. He was married to Mary Scott and had fourteen children. He is buried in Old Rapides Cemetery in Pineville, Louisiana.
James Madison Wells belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: An organization that "send[s] and receiv[es] messages by electrical or radio signals, or the special equipment used for this purpose." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Telegraph Companies--New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company (Jackson, Miss.)

gloss.p: Located in Jackson, Mississippi, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Kentucky, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the Mississippi State legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Louisville, Kentucky, New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees was a telegraph company established between 1857 and 1860. New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees were the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest. On February 3, 1860, the Mississippi State House amended the act which incorporated the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees, changing the company's name to Southwestern Telegraph Company. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Mobile, Alabama, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)
"The crime of getting money by deceiving people." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)

Operating at the state level, the Louisiana State Executive Department was established by Article 3 of the Louisiana Constitution in 1812 and serves as part of the executive branch of the Louisiana state government. It is led by the Louisiana State Governor, who directly presides over the Cabinet. (Wikipedia)

div.p: Terms and Conditions on which this and all Messages are Received by this Company.

In order to guard against and correct as much as possible some of the errors arising from atmospheric and other causes appertaining to telegraphy, every important message should be repeated, by being sent back from the station at which it is to be received to the station from which it is originally sent. Half the usual price will be charged for repeating the message; and while this Company in good faith will endeavour to send messages correctly and promptly, it will not be responsible for errors or delays in the transmission or delivery, nor for the non-delivery of repeated messages, beyond two hundred times the sum paid for sending the message, unless a special agreement for insurance be made in writing, and the amount of risk specified on this agreement, and paid at the time of sending the message. Nor will the Company be responsible for any error or delay in the trnasmission or delivery, or for the non-delivery, of any unrepeated message, beyond the amount paid for sending the same, unless in like manner specially insured, and amount of risk stated hereon, and paid for at the time. No liaiblity is assumed for errors in cipher or obscure messages; nor is any liability assumed by this Company for any error or neglect by any other Company over whose lines this message may be sent to reach its destination, and this Company is hereby made the agent of the sender of this message to forward it over the lines extending beyond those of this Company. No agent or employeeis allowed to vary these terms, or make any other or verbal agreement, nor any promise as to the time of performance; and no one but a Superintendent is authorized to make a special agreement for insurance. These terms apply through the whole course of this message, on all lines by which it may be transmitted.

Jackson Apl 30 186
By Telegraph from New Orleans 186
To Gov of Mississippi
Requisition has been issued for the arrest of one John O Noble, for obtaining Money under false pretences
